citation.article-title: Sanguibacter antarcticus sp. nov., isolated from Antarctic sea sand.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Sanguibacter antarcticus sp. nov.
Sanguibacter antarcticus (an.tarc′ti.cus. L. masc. adj. antarcticus southern, pertaining to the Antarctic, the geographical origin of the type strain).
Gram-positive, catalase-positive, oxidase-negative, facultatively anaerobic and mesophilic.
Cells are irregular and motile rods (0.6–45×0.4–0.6 μm) with sparse peritrichous flagella.
Colonies are yellow, circular and convex with entire edges.
Growth occurs under aerobic and anaerobic conditions.
Growth occurs at pH 4–9 (optimum pH 5–6) and with 0–7 % NaCl (optimum 2–5 %).
Acid is produced from l-arabinose, cellobiose, aesculin, fructose, gentiobiose, glucose, glycogen, maltose, mannitol, ribose, starch, sucrose, trehalose, turanose and d-xylose (API 50CHB).

Acid is not produced from N-acetylglucosamine, adonitol, amygdalin, d-arabinose, d-arabitol, l-arabitol, arbutin, dulcitol, erythritol, d-fucose, l-fucose, galactose, gluconate, glycerol, inositol, inulin, 2-ketogluconate, 5-ketogluconate, lactose, d-lyxose, mannose, melibiose, melezitose, methyl α-d-glucoside, methyl α-d-mannoside, methyl β-d-xyloside, raffinose, rhamnose, salicin, sorbitol, sorbose, d-tagatose, xylitol or l-xylose (API 50CHB).

Citrate is utilized and acetoin is produced weakly, but negative for arginine dihydrolase, cytochrome oxidase, β-galactosidase, gelatinase, H2S production, indole production, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase, tryptophan deaminase and urease (API 20E).
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite and nitrogen (API 20NE).
Predominant cellular fatty acids are anteiso-C15 : 0 (50.5 %), C16 : 0 (9.6 %), anteiso-C13 : 0 (7.6 %) and iso-C16 : 0 (7.5 %).
The type strain is KOPRI 21702T (=KCTC 13143T =JCM 14623T =DSM 18966T), isolated from a sea sand sample from King George Island, Antarctica.
The genomic DNA G+C content of the type strain is 69.5 mol%.
